relationships.evidence_text: Welcome to the Why On Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry.
we are visiting with Biochar Expert and Professor Emeritus David Laird.
he is currently founder and president of N Sense Inc. an agri-technology company and professor Emeritus at Iowa State University.
David Laird received a PhD in Agronomy from Iowa State University in 1987.
he is currently founder and president of N Sense Inc.
As a professor, he mentored 20 masters in PhD students.
He is author and co-author of over 157 referee journal articles and book chapters related to Biochar.
His publications have been cited over 20,000 times.
his H index is 60.
Previously, he served as editor of Geoderma.

relationships.target: Soil Science Society of America Journal

He is a fellow in the American Society of Agronomy.
and the soil science society of America.
we've got so much to cover that relates to regenerative agriculture.
and carbon sequestration.
food production yield improvements and other topics related to Biochar.
Biochar can also be made virtually any source of biological materials.
You can put it in what's known as a pyrolyzer and turn it into Biochar.
Pyrolyzer is a little different from a campfire.
It's a material that you find naturally in soils.
Pyrrigenic, it came from those wildfires and this is true all over the world.
Char is very much a natural thing.
it got incorporated into our soils.

A lot of the new science began when a number of people discovered the so-called terapreta soils.
this is a really cool story. This really incredible biome down there.
they had intense leaching.
you've got these soils that are deep red soils.
they have low activity clays so they don't hold nutrients.
those tropical soils can hard set. Turn into stone if you dry them out.
Yet it supports this incredible biome.
that leaf has nutrients and it has potassium, phosphorus, nitrogen.
the fungi are eating away at that leaf and reciclose all those nutrients back into the bio.
they figured out that they could basically dig a trench and put woody biomass in there, burn it, turn it into charcoal and incorporate that into the soil.
it would improve the quality of those soils.
If you raise the pH by putting char and ash in.

they are human-made soils.
they are still the prize horticultural cropping soils down along the Amazon.
discovery of these terra credit soils ignited interest in biochar.

the recognition that the terra credit soils were anthropogenic and that the use of charcoal and soils could have a real positive impact on soil quality, soil health.

when they're absorbed there, they are stabilized, reducing the rate at which microbes turn them into CO2.

relationships.evidence_text: turning the woody biomass or other agricultural residues or other biological materials into biochar.
if you look at plant tissue, a leaf, right? It's a mixture of a number of different molecules.
a lot of it is what we call cellulose. Cellulose is a lot of sugar molecules.
but it also has proteins in it.
amino acids have a nitrogen in them and sulfur and some other things.
all of those biopolymers are basically lunch for soil microorganisms.
that's what they eat.
if a leaf falls on the surface of the soil.
the half-life of the carbon that is in that leaf... It's measuring a couple of months.
after three, four, five years, 99 percent of the carbon that was in that leaf is back in the atmosphere.
that's because the leaf is lunch for the microbes.

relationships.relationship: when heated in pyrolyzer turns into
relationships.evidence_text: If you take that same leaf and you put it in a pyrolyzer, you heat it up to about 500 degrees centigrade.
It thermally decomposes.
the leaf is lunch for the microbes.

if you take that same leaf and you put it in a pyrolyzer, you heat it up to about 500 degrees centigrade. It thermally decomposes, and you're going to have the smoky material coming off the top. But you'll be left with the char.
the char is chemically different. It's dominated by carbon.
Also has some ash mixed in with it.
The ash is mostly oxides and of minerals like potassium, phosphorus, calcium, magnesium, and carbonates.
if you have a high ash biomass, a high ash leaf, then you'll get more ash less carbon.
if you have a biomass that has a lot of organic matter, very little ash in it, then you're going to get a carbon-rich char.
that typically comes with pine wood, right? It gives you a really carbon-rich char.
the carbon molecule start bonding to each other.
everybody knows that a diamond, right, is carbon.
if I took a diamond and put it in the soil, it's going to be there for millions of years.
the chemical form of carbon matters.
We can also have carbon in the form of what's called graphite.
graphite is also for all intensive purposes inert to microorganisms.
char is somewhere between graphite and these biopolymers that are in the leaf.
It has a structure of carbon-carbon bonds and some of them are aromatic.
it is not very digestible to the microorganisms.
99% of the carbon is going to go back to the atmosphere in a couple of years.
the half-life of the carbon in biochar... it's going to be measured in hundreds if not thousands of years.
that is the real reason that biochar is a good agent for carbon sequestration.
